items.name: Friendly
entries: A beast with a Friendly disposition is trained fairly easily, but may become confused due to its inexperience. On a failed {@skill Animal Handling} check to command it, it will take the {@action Dodge} or {@action Disengage} action and move towards you up to its speed, stopping at your side.

items.name: Skittish
entries: A beast with a Skittish disposition is meek and easily cowed, but also reticent to face danger. On a failed {@skill Animal Handling} check to command it, it will take the {@action Dodge}, {@action Disengage} or {@action Dash} action (at the DM's discretion) and move as far as it is able to away from danger.

items.name: Aggressive
entries: A beast with an Aggressive disposition is quick to bite or scratch if not handled firmly. On a failed {@skill Animal Handling} check to command it, it will {@action attack} the creature nearest to it, without distinguishing between foe and ally. If there are multiple creatures within the same distance, it will choose a target at random, or attack multiple creatures if it has multiple attacks available.

items.name: Obstinate
entries: A beast with the Obstinate disposition stubbornly refuses all but the most skilled commands. On a failed {@skill Animal Handling} check to command it, it will take the {@action Dodge} action and take no movement.

data.name: Cover Page & Credits

items: {@link Jared Ondricek|https://watercolors.giantsoup.com/index.html)} {@note Page Textures—unused in this conversion}

entries: And many thanks to {@link MobiusFlip|https://www.reddit.com/user/MobiusFlip} and the folks at {@link r/UnearthedArcana|https://www.reddit.com/r/UnearthedArcana/} for brainstorming help!

I've always really liked the idea of a character who fits the ranger archetype—a master of the wilderness, highly skilled at tracking and foraging, a precise and deadly hunter—without having to be a half-druid. I'm definitely not opposed to the magical ranger, I just feel like there's room for the mundane kind, too.

The {@class Rogue|PHB|Scout Rogue|Scout|XGE} does a pretty good job - a mobile ambusher at home in the wild - but it's missing something. It still plays like a {@class rogue|PHB}, focused on getting one big Sneak Attack off per turn, whereas the ranger is traditionally more about multiple quick attacks. Also, the only actual nature-specific flavor is one 3rd-level trait, which is just extra Expertise—not terrible, but a bit bland.

Early on in 5e's lifespan, a {@class Ranger (Spell-less)|UAModifyingClasses|spell-less ranger} rework was proposed in the {@link Modifying Classes UA article|https://dnd.wizards.com/articles/unearthed-arcana/modifying-classes}. This was a decent attempt, but mostly served to turn the ranger into a {@class Fighter|PHB|Battle Master|Battle Master} with some healing capability and poison resistance. {@classFeature Call Natural Allies|Ranger (Spell-less)|UAModifyingClasses|13} also feels too much like magic to me. It also does nothing to address the classic complaints about the 5e ranger, namely that their class features are too niche and weak, mostly focused around exploration rules that often get ignored anyway.

In 2019, Pathfinder Second Edition released with a {@link new version of the ranger|https://pf2etools.com/classes.html#ranger_crb} that was quite well-received, and notably did not automatically have spells (which could later be obtained {@link through feats|https://pf2etools.com/feats.html#aerial%20boomerang_pt%3akin,flstclass:ranger=1,flopclass:extend}). This followed in the tradition of the Fourth Edition ranger. This ranger has an innate {@spell hunter's mark}-like feature called {@link Hunt Prey|https://pf2etools.com/classes.html#ranger_crb,state:feature=s0-2#accurate%20flurry_apg}, which has one of three effects based on your choice of {@link Hunter's Edge feature|https://pf2etools.com/classes.html#ranger_crb,state:feature=s0-3#accurate%20flurry_apg}, taking the place of a subclass. This ability, and several later features and feats of the class, provided some great inspiration for what a spell-less ranger can look like.

Then, {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} came out and included some nice enhancements for the 5e ranger class via {@5etools variant features|classes.html#ranger_phb,flstsource:dmg=0~erlw=0~egw=0~exploringeberron=0~ftd=0~ggr=0~mot=0~phb=0~scag=0~tdcsr=0~vrgr=0~xge=0,flopsource:extend,flstmiscellaneous:reprinted=0~sidekick=0,flopmiscellaneous:extend}. I liked the additions provided by {@classFeature Deft Explorer|Ranger|PHB|1|TCE}, but wasn't a fan of how they replaced Natural Explorer altogether—I think it's best to keep that niche exploration flavor but buff it to be more useful in a combat-focused game. Additionally, a lot of Tasha's improvements add extra spells or magical effects—see how the {@subclassFeature Primal Companion|Ranger|PHB|Beast Master|PHB|3|TCE|Beast Master now uses a primal spirit instead of a trained animal}—turning the ranger into what increasingly feels like a druid with a bow.

Despite my dalliance with {@link Pathfinder|https://pf2etools.com/} I still love {@5etools D&D Fifth Edition|index.html}, and I wanted to be make this kind of ranger available to 5e players. It's meant to be a robust martial class, with mechanics that are engaging but also easy to use. I kept a close eye on the other martial classes in the game, to make sure that this ranger could keep up with them without stepping on their toes, and could complement them through multiclassing without being too powerful.

Keeping all these inspirations and considerations in mind, and doing my best to make up for lost spell utility while staying in balance with all other classes, I give you the {@class Martial Ranger|TMR}. I hope you enjoy!

data.name: The Ranger
entries: Rough and wild looking, a human stalks alone through the shadows of trees, hunting the orcs he knows are planning a raid on a nearby farm. Clutching a shortsword in each hand, he becomes a whirlwind of steel, cutting down one enemy after another.

After tumbling away from a cone of freezing air, an elf finds her feet and draws back her bow to loose an arrow at the white dragon. Shrugging off the wave of fear that emanates from the dragon like the cold of its breath, she sends one arrow after another to find the gaps between the dragon's thick scales.

Holding his hand high, a half-elf whistles to the hawk that circles high above him, calling the bird back to his side. Whispering instructions in Elvish, he points to the owlbear he's been tracking and sends the hawk to distract the creature while he readies his bow.

Far from the bustle of cities and towns, past the hedges that shelter the most distant farms from the terrors of the wild, amid the dense-packed trees of trackless forests and across wide and empty plains, rangers keep their unending watch.

entries.name: Rugged Survivalists
entries: Rangers may live on the fringes of civilization, but the wilderness is their true home. Rangers have a deep connection to the land they make their home, and all its flora and fauna. Living off the land is second nature to them: they are well-versed in tracking, hunting and gathering, reading the subtle messages hidden in the terrain. The ranger lives in this world, yet stands apart from it; their knowledge, ingenuity and craftsmanship set them apart from wild beasts. Instead, the ranger lives in balance between nature and civilization, one foot in each world, protecting each from the other's encroachment, and threats from beyond.

As master warriors of the wilderness, rangers are rarely satisfied with mundane quarry, and learn specialized techniques to hunt the monsters that threaten their beloved balance: humanoid raiders, rampaging beasts and monstrosities, terrible giants, and deadly dragons. They learn to track their quarry as a predator does, moving stealthily through the wilds and hiding themselves in brush and rubble. Once they have the scent, a ranger will follow their prey to the ends of the earth, and finish them with deadly skill.

entries.name: Roving Adventurers
entries: Many rangers make their living as hunters, guides or trackers in their home territory, but others hear the call of new lands to explore, greater prey to conquer, and helpless people in need of protection and guidance. Taking little with them but what they can carry and perhaps a beast companion, these rangers pursue the calling of the adventurer.

Accustomed to life far from the comforts of a dry bed and a hot bath, rangers are well-suited to the adventuring lifestyle, though their fierce independence may put them at odds with fellow travelers. Faced with city-bred adventurers who grouse and whine about the hardships of the wild, rangers respond with some mixture of amusement, frustration, and compassion. But they quickly learn that other adventurers who can carry their own weight in a fight are worth any extra burden. Coddled city folk might not know how to feed themselves or find fresh water in the wild, but they make up for it in other ways.

entries.name: Creating a Ranger
entries: As you create your ranger character, consider the nature of the training that gave you your particular capabilities. Were you self-taught, a recluse who learned combat skills, tracking, and natural remedies through the necessity of surviving in the wilds? Did you train with a mentor, wandering the wilds together until you mastered the ranger's ways? Did you leave your apprenticeship, or was your mentor slain—perhaps by the same kind of monster that became your favored enemy? Or perhaps you learned your skills as part of a band of rangers affiliated with a druidic circle, trained in mystic paths as well as wilderness lore.

What's the source of your particular expertise in a certain kind of enemy? Did a monster kill someone you loved or destroy your home village? Or did you see too many innocent creatures destroyed by these monsters and commit yourself to reining in their depredations? Is your adventuring career a continuation of your work in protecting the borderlands, or a significant change?
What made you join up with a band of adventurers? Do you find it challenging to teach new allies the ways of the wild, or do you welcome the relief from solitude that they offer?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a ranger quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom. (Some rangers who focus on {@skill athletics} and heavy weapons make Strength higher than Dexterity.) Second, choose the {@background outlander} background.

entries.name: Creation
entries: {@note Credit to {@link u/FragSauce's|https://www.reddit.com/user/FragSauce/} Soul Binder class for inspiration on the companion creation system!}

entries.name: Step 1: Size
entries: Your companion is a Tiny, Small or Medium beast (your choice). If you are an {@class Martial Ranger|TMR|Outrider|Outrider|TMR}, it may also be Large.

entries.name: Step 2: Abilities and Defenses
entries: Your companion is proficient in {@skill Perception}, {@skill Survival}, either {@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Stealth}, and either {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Acrobatics}, as well as Strength and Dexterity saving throws. It has one of the following ability score arrays:

Its Armor Class = 10 + your proficiency bonus (PB) + its Dexterity modifier, and it has a number of Hit Dice equal to your ranger level. If it is Bulky, its hit points equal 6 + six times your ranger level, and its Hit Dice are {@dice d10|d10s}. If it is Middling, its hit points equal 5 + five times your ranger level, and its Hit Dice are {@dice d8|d8s}. If it is Light, its hit points equal 4 + four times your ranger level, and its Hit Dice are {@dice d6|d6s}.

entries.name: Step 3: Senses
entries: Your companion has {@sense darkvision} 60 ft. and two of the following Sense features. You can replace one Sense with one Special Movement feature.

items.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

items.name: Keen Sight
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

items.name: Keen Smell
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

items.name: Keen Touch
entries: The beast has {@sense tremorsense|MM} 40 ft.

items.name: Echolocation
entries: The beast has {@sense blindsight} 60 ft. as long as it is not {@condition deafened}.

entries.name: Step 4: Speed
entries: Your companion has one of the following Speed options:

items.name: Land-based
entries: 40 ft, swim 10 ft.

items.name: Climber
entries: 30 ft, climb 30 ft.

items.name: Flyer
entries: 10 ft, fly 60 ft. Cannot use the Bulky array.

items.name: Aquatic
entries: 5 ft, swim 60 ft.

items.name: Amphibian
entries: 30 ft, swim 30 ft.

items.name: Burrower
entries: 30 ft, burrow 10 ft.

entries.name: Step 5: Special Movement
entries: Your companion has one of the following special Special Movement features, or two if replacing a Sense.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: The beast can breathe air and water.

items.name: Flyby
entries: The beast doesn't provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|PHB|opportunity attacks} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

items.name: Hold Breath
entries: The beast can hold its breath for 15 minutes.

items.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the beast can long jump up to 25 feet.

items.name: Slither
entries: The beast does not need limbs to walk, swim or climb.

items.name: Spider Climb
entries: The beast can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

items.name: Standing Leap
entries: The beast's long jump is up to 10 feet and its high jump is up to 5 feet, with or without a running start.

items.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

items.name: Swift
entries: The beast's speeds all increase by 5 feet from base.

items.name: Water Breathing
entries: The beast can only breathe underwater. It has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on {@skill Stealth} checks while underwater.

entries.name: Step 6: Natural Weapons
entries: Your companion is proficient in two of the following natural weapons. Note that it must have teeth to bite, claws to claw, and a stinger to sting (though sting can be re-flavored as an alternate bite). Pummel can use any blunt natural weapon the creature possesses, including fists or hooves. Gore can use horns, antlers or tusks. Tail can use any long appendage: a tail, tentacle or even a tongue.
Note that beasts can {@action grapple} without a free hand, using their mouth, or body in the case of constrictors.

items.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d8} + Str piercing damage. If the beast hits a target with a bite attack, it can use its bonus action to attempt to {@action grapple} that target.

items.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} finesse, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d4} + Str/Dex slashing damage. If the beast makes a claw attack using its action, it can make another claw attack as a bonus action.

items.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d6} + Str piercing damage. If the beast uses Charge on this attack, the damage die increases to a {@dice d12}.

items.name: Pummel
entries: {@atk mw} reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d6} + Str bludgeoning damage. If the beast hits a target with a pummel attack, it can use its bonus action to attempt to {@action shove} that target.

items.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} finesse, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d4} + Str/Dex piercing damage. If the target fails its saving throw against Envenom, it takes an additional {@damage 1d8} poison damage.

items.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw}, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}{@dice 1d6} + Str bludgeoning damage.

items.name: Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by webbing. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 10} + PB Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; HP 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

entries.name: Step 7: Special Attack
entries: Your companion has one of the following Special Attack features.

items.name: Charge {@recharge 5}
entries: If the beast moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a natural weapon on the same turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} + PB Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

items.name: Pounce {@recharge 5}
entries: If the beast makes a long jump at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a natural weapon on the same turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} + PB Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

items.name: Dive {@recharge 5}
entries: If the beast flies or swims at least 30 feet downward toward a target and then hits it with a natural weapon on the same turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} + PB Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Crush
entries: If the beast succeeds on an {@skill Athletics} check to {@action grapple}, it deals additional bludgeoning damage to the target equal to its Strength modifier.

items.name: Envenom
entries: If the beast succeeds on a bite or sting attack, the target must make a {@dc 10} + PB Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the target is {@condition poisoned}. It can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a successful save, it is no longer {@condition poisoned}.

items.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the beast's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

items.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The beast has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on melee attack rolls against any creature that has less than half its maximum hit points.

entries.name: Step 8: Special Recovery
entries: It has one of the following Special Recovery features, which can be used once and recharges on a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

items.name: Relentless
entries: If the beast takes damage less than 3 your + ranger level that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

items.name: Second Wind
entries: The beast can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to {@dice 1d6 + summonclasslevel|1d6 + your ranger level.}

items.name: Toughen Up
entries: The beast can use its bonus action to give itself advantage on Constitution saving throws against being {@condition poisoned} or {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute, and gain temporary hit points equal to {@dice ceil(summonclasslevel/2)|half your ranger level (rounded up)}.

entries.name: Note on Recharge
entries: Actions labeled {@i Recharge X-Y} follow the same rules as described in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}:

{@i At the start of each of the beast's turns, roll a {@dice d6}. If the roll is one of the numbers in the recharge notation, the beast regains the use of the special ability. The ability also recharges when the beast finishes a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.}

entries.name: Examples
entries: The following are examples of companions you can take at level 3, as their stat blocks would appear at that level. Note that these are suggestions, and not the only way to build this type of creature.

data.name: Appendix B: Companion Training
entries: When replacing a lost beast companion, a player may choose to train a new companion themself instead of procuring a pre-trained animal. The DM should generally not present this as the default option, but instead as a potentially interesting challenge that the player may enjoy roleplaying through. They should be aware that choosing to train a companion mid-adventure may decrease their combat effectiveness.

All wild beasts are individuals, and therefore training a beast into a companion is not a one-size-fits-all approach. A beast's disposition determines how long it will take to train it, and how it will act when not obeying your commands.

Once per turn when the ranger attempts to command their companion to move or use its action, they must make an {@skill Animal Handling} check against the creature's Animal Handling DC, which is based on their disposition and how much time remains in their training. On a success, the beast does as commanded, as normal; on a failure, it acts according to its disposition, as described below.

The DM determines an untrained animal's disposition, either by choosing directly or by rolling a {@dice d4} and using the table below. A beast's Animal Handling DC decreases by 2 after each successive week of training. When the DC would decrease to 8, the beast is fully trained and no longer requires {@skill Animal Handling} checks to command.

data.name: Appendix E: Companion Magic Items
entries: Beast companions have three attunement slots and follow thesame rules for magic items that player characters do.
